bestBHT.bht: We are called to embody a forgiveness that is infinite, continuous, and everlasting. Our Lord's teaching on forgiveness goes beyond a specific number, instead prescribing a forgiveness that is limitless and freely given. Whether interpreting seventy times seven as 490 or 77, the essence remains the same - forgiveness has no bounds. We are to practice forgiveness qualitatively, not quantitatively, extending it generously and without restriction. Let us embrace the transformative power of unlimited forgiveness as examples of Christ's boundless grace and mercy in our interactions with others.

Henry Alford: 22.] On seventy times seven, Chrysostom remarks,*that our Lord does not here lay down a number, but prescribes that which is infinite and continuous and everlasting.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Until seventy times seven—that is, so long as it shall be needed and sought: you are never to come to the point of refusing forgiveness sincerely asked.
You are never to come to the point of refusing forgiveness sincerely asked.
You are never to come to the point of refusing forgiveness.
Albert Barnes: Till seven times? - The Jews caught that a man was to forgive another three times, but not the fourth.
I say not unto thee, Until seven times, but, Until seventy times seven - The meaning is, that we are not to limit our forgiveness to any fixed number of times.
If he does not ask us to forgive him, yet we are not at liberty to follow him with revenge and malice, but are still to treat him kindly and to do him good.
Marvin Vincent: Even so, the practice was terribly different.
Christ is not specifying a number of times greater than the limit of seven. He means that there is to be no limit.
Philip Schaff: Until seventy times seven. It is doubtful whether the original means 490 or 77 . But in either case it is a symbolical expression for never-ending forgiveness.
Love is not to be limited by the multiplication table.
Archibald T. Robertson: Until seventy times seven. It is not clear whether this idiom means seventy-seven or as the Revised Version has it (490 times).
The same ambiguity is seen in Genesis 4:24, the LXX text by omitting κα. In the Test. of the Twelve Patriarchs, Benj. vii. 4, it is used in the sense of seventy times seven.

But it really makes little difference because Jesus clearly means unlimited forgiveness in either case. 'The unlimited revenge of primitive man has given place to the unlimited forgiveness of Christians' (McNeile).
John Gill: Christ's meaning is, that a man should be all the days, and every day of his life, forgiving those that sin against him, as often as they repent and acknowledge their fault."
No time is to be set for the exercise of the grace of forgiveness.
As often as there are objects and occasions, though ever so many and frequent, forgiveness should be used.
John Wesley: Till seventy times seven — That is, as often as there is occasion. A certain number is put for an uncertain.

bhtAttempts.bht: We are called to embody a type of forgiveness that is infinite, continuous, and everlasting. It is not about a specific number of times but rather an attitude of never refusing forgiveness when it is genuinely sought. Our Lord's directive is clear - forgiveness should never be limited or quantified, but should be freely given. While the customary practice may have been far from this standard, Jesus calls us to transcend the limited mindset and embrace forgiveness as a qualitative and boundless act. Whether the idiom seventy times seven denotes 490 or 77, the message remains the same - forgiveness should have no limits. Love is not to be confined by numbers or calculations; instead, it should flow freely and generously. Thus, we are to continually forgive others as long as there is a need and an acknowledgment of fault. May we extend forgiveness without restriction, for no fixed number of times can set bounds on the grace and mercy we are called to demonstrate.
